content.headline: AMD Finds That Even AI Has Its Limits
content.summary: Advanced Micro Devices can sell all the artificial intelligence chips it is able to make—and then some.  Such was apparent Wednesday, when AMD’s share price slipped about 4% [following its fourth-quarter results](https://www.wsj.com/livecoverage/stock-market-today-dow-jones-earnings-01-30-2024/card/amd-forecasts-shaky-first-quarter-sales-despite-ai-boom-uZv5In10JW4Qapr6QLKJ?mod=Searchresults_pos1&page=1).  The results included a disappointing revenue forecast for the first quarter despite booming demand for the company’s [new GPU chip designed for AI use in data centers](https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/amds-piece-of-the-ai-pie-will-need-to-prove-sticky-46f39e16), where it [competes with Nvidia](https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/nvidias-rivals-prepare-their-ai-assault-0cf9ba01).

content.headline: White House AI council meets Monday as legislative action stalls
content.summary: The White House artificial intelligence council is meeting Monday, three months after President Joe Biden signed an executive order that aims to reduce the risks AI poses.  White House Deputy Chief of Staff Bruce Reed, who will convene the council meeting Monday, said in a statement the federal government had made significant progress in the prior 90 days on AI, saying Biden's "directive to us is move fast and fix things."  The White House said nine government agencies - including Defense, Transportation, Treasury, and Health and Human Services - submitted risk assessments to the Department of Homeland Security required under Biden's order.
